data.title: Britain’s first air ace is finally on film
data.meta_description: The story of Lanoe Hawker’s rise to become Britain’s first air ace during the First World War and his death at the hands of the Red Baron has inspired a new fil
data.text:
The story of Lanoe Hawker’s rise to become Britain’s first air ace during the First World War and his death at the hands of the Red Baron has inspired a new film featuring one of his descendants.

The pilot, who won a Victoria Cross after fixing a machinegun to his reconnaissance aircraft, is the subject of Hawker, a short film about the air combat pioneer who was killed by the warfare he helped to invent.

Daniel Arbon, the director, crowdfunded £20,000 for his 23-minute film, in which he also appears. Although the film is modest in scale, he hopes that it will lead to a bigger project that is able to relay Hawker’s life and death.

Using a contact at the Great War Aviation
